block.p: The Dutch Seek to Ease Restrictions on Euthanasia The Netherlands, where mercy killings and the assisted suicide of terminally ill patients have been widely tolerated, is expected to take a further step this fall with legislation to decriminalize such acts if certain criteria are met.

The Dutch Seek to Ease Restrictions on Euthanasia The Netherlands, where mercy killings and the assisted suicide of terminally ill patients have been widely tolerated, is expected to take a further step this fall with legislation to decriminalize such acts if certain criteria are met.

58 Migrants Dead in Britain British customs officers searching a consignment of imported tomatoes aboard a Dutch truck in the Channel port of Dover found the bodies of 58 Asian men and women inside. It was not clear how the people in the truck -- presumed to be poor migrants being smuggled into Britain -- had died. Two men survived and the driver, identified only as a citizen of the Netherlands, was arrested.

New Interest in North Korea South Koreans have become enthralled with all things North Korean since North Korea and South Korea vowed to pursue peace and reconciliation last week. The summit meeting apparently has forced South Koreans to reassess their decades-old view of North Korea as a mortal enemy.

The Clinton administration, after years of directing sanctions and suspicion toward defiant governments from North Korea to Iran, abruptly declared that ''rogue nations'' no longer exist in the world, but, instead, are ''states of concern.''

New U.S.-China Drug Effort The United States and China agreed to step up cooperation in the fight against illegal drugs, especially heroin and methamphetamine. The agreement was announced in Beijing by Barry R. McCaffrey, the retired Army general who is the director of the White House drug-control office.
Zedillo Rejects Accusations President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico assailed opposition candidates who warned of possible irregularities in the July 2 election for president.
Nancy Marchand The character actress most recently known for her role as a mob matriarch in ''The Sopranos'' was 71.

High Court Bans Prayers Led by Students at Games The Supreme Court ruled that student-led prayers at high school football games are unconstitutional, even when participation is voluntary. Ruling 6 to 3 in a Texas case, the court strongly reaffirmed earlier decisions against officially sponsored prayer in public schools.

In a rare excursion into foreign policy, the high court unanimously struck down a Massachusetts law barring state agencies from dealing with companies that do business in Myanmar, saying it impinges on Congress's diplomatic goals.

Medicaid Coverage Lost Nearly a million people have lost Medicaid coverage and have probably become uninsured since Congress and the states began overhauling welfare programs in 1996, a consumer group said.

Federal Hate Crime Bill Senators of both parties condemned crimes based on race, sex or sexual orientation, in an emotional prelude to a vote set for today on creating a federal statute on hate crimes.

House Bars Tobacco Suit Loan The House voted to bar the Justice Department from accepting funds from another agency to pay for a federal suit against the tobacco industry. Attorney General Janet Reno had said the step would force her to drop the multibillion-dollar case.
Nader Sues Over Debates Ralph Nader, the Green Party presidential candidate, filed a lawsuit against the Federal Election Commission over the corporate financing of presidential debates.

G.O.P. Platform Meeting Republicans turned their first official platform meeting into a showcase for the party's ideas on education, Medicare and Social Security. But the party's ideological fault lines on abortion were apparent.

Political Odd Couple Splits Lenora Fulani, whose political views hew as far to the left as Patrick J. Buchanan's do to the right, resigned as co-chairman of his presidential campaign, accusing him of destroying their political partnership by pressing his strong social conservative positions.

Thousands Attend Mass Consecrating Archbishop Edward M. Egan was installed as archbishop of New York during a televised Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral that was attended by 4,000, including an array of prominent political and government figures.
City to Sue Pistol Makers Mayor Giuliani said New York would sue handgun manufacturers, seeking tens of millions of dollars in compensation for injuries and other damage caused by illegal gun use.
Times to Build New Home The New York Times is expected to sign an agreement with the city and state this week to build a 40-story headquarters on Eighth Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets.

Hearing on 1975 Killing A judge in Connecticut will hold a hearing today on whether Michael Skakel, 39, charged with murdering 15-year-old Martha Moxley in Greenwich 25 years ago, should be tried as a juvenile or an adult.

'Natural' Does Not Mean Safe Many women bypass hormone replacement therapy for ''natural'' alternatives containing plant estrogens. Experts worry that some are being overzealous or taking unsafe doses, especially women with estrogen-dependent breast cancer.

A Jacqueline Kennedy Show The Metropolitan Museum of Art said the White House fashions of Jacqueline Kennedy would replace the canceled Coco Chanel retrospective as the Met's grand annual exhibition to benefit its Costume Institute. And it will be in April, not December.

'Macbeth' Closing Early The Broadway production of ''Macbeth,'' starring Kelsey Grammer, will close on Sunday, after only 13 regular performances and five weeks earlier than planned. The production has gotten poor reviews.
Seagram-Vivendi Deal Seagram will announce its acquisition for $34 billion in stock by Vivendi, the French water utility transforming itself into a telecommunications and entertainment giant.
Complaints of Bias at Nextel More than 300 current and former employees of the wireless carrier intend to file complaints of racial and sexual bias, lawyers said.
Pursuit of Saatchi & Saatchi Publicis was said to be planning to buy Saatchi & Saatchi, the British advertising agency, for at least $1.5 billion in stock.

Nuclear Fuel Company Troubles The board of United States Enrichment, the uranium-enrichment company created by the Clinton administration in 1998, meets tomorrow to discuss closing one of its two plants to try to avert bankruptcy.
Lakers Win N.B.A. Title Los Angeles, trailing Indiana for much of Game 6, defeated the Pacers, 116-111, to capture their 12th championship -- and their first of the post-Magic Johnson era.
